articles.headline: A New Weapon for Battling Cellphones in Theaters: Laser Beams
articles.snippet: Some performance spaces in China aim light beams at patrons to discourage them from using cellphones during shows.
articles.abstract: Some performance spaces in China aim light beams at patrons to discourage them from using cellphones during shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Audience members using cellphones bedevil performers and presenters around the world. But in China, theaters and other venues have adopted what they say is an effective — others might say disturbing — solution.

articles.headline: Putin Orders Start of Syria Withdrawal, Saying Goals Are Achieved
articles.snippet: The order from the Kremlin came as the United Nations was trying to revive peace talks to stop the conflict, which has created a humanitarian catastrophe.
articles.abstract: The order from the Kremlin came as the United Nations was trying to revive peace talks to stop the conflict, which has created a humanitarian catastrophe.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday ordered the withdrawal of the “main part” of Russian forces in Syria, a surprise move that reflected what he called the Kremlin’s achievement of nearly all its objectives in the war-torn country.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: Moneyball for Book Publishers: A Detailed Look at How We Read
articles.snippet: A reader analytics company in London wants to use data on our reading habits to transform how publishers acquire, edit and market books.
articles.abstract: A reader analytics company in London wants to use data on our reading habits to transform how publishers acquire, edit and market books.
articles.lead_paragraph: Andrew Rhomberg wants to be the Billy Beane of the book world.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Alter and Karl Russell

articles.headline: Upheaval at Breitbart News as Workers Resign and Accusations Fly
articles.snippet: Employees who left in recent days said that the website’s unabashed embrace of Donald Trump, particularly at the seeming expense of its own reporter, was unacceptable.
articles.abstract: Employees who left in recent days said that the website’s unabashed embrace of Donald Trump, particularly at the seeming expense of its own reporter, was unacceptable.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a proudly renegade voice of the populist right, Breitbart News has long delighted in bedeviling liberals and establishment Republicans alike, emerging in recent years as one of the nation’s leading conservative media outlets.

articles.headline: Investors Increasingly Bullish on Energy Sector
articles.snippet: Across the oil industry, investors have been placing their bets that prices have hit bottom. But there is still a way to go before a full recovery.
articles.abstract: Across the oil industry, investors have been placing their bets that prices have hit bottom. But there is still a way to go before a full recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was one of the darkest periods of the oil market slump. The global economy was showing fresh signs of slowing, and crude prices were collapsing so steeply that virtually every well in America was unprofitable.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Unpacking a Chinese Company’s U.S. Hotel Buying Spree
articles.snippet: Chinese companies have been on a foreign acquisition spree in recent years, looking abroad for deals in an effort to diversify.
articles.abstract: Chinese companies have been on a foreign acquisition spree in recent years, looking abroad for deals in an effort to diversify.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Japanese began buying trophy properties like Rockefeller Center in the late 1980s, there was an intense reaction.

articles.headline: 2 Front-Runners, Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton, Find Their Words Can Be Weapons
articles.snippet: Five states vote on Tuesday, and the front-runners, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton, fell under attack over their perceived weaknesses.
articles.abstract: Five states vote on Tuesday, and the front-runners, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton, fell under attack over their perceived weaknesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The vulnerabilities of the leading presidential candidates were laid bare on Monday as rivals sought to portray Hillary Clinton as being at odds with the white working class and Donald J. Trump as a misogynist who did not deserve the support of women in the five states that vote on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Al Qaeda’s Branch in Africa Makes a Lethal Comeback
articles.snippet: Only a few years after French troops scattered its fighters, Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb has regrouped and extended its reach in three nations.
articles.abstract: Only a few years after French troops scattered its fighters, Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb has regrouped and extended its reach in three nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Only a few years after French troops broke up its desert stronghold and scattered its fighters into the dunes, Al Qaeda’s branch in West Africa has regrouped and extended its reach, storming into new territory across three nations.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey, Eric Schmitt and Rukmini Callimachi

articles.headline: Battered Valeant Stock Drops a Further 50% After Weak Guidance
articles.snippet: The company, which is facing inquiries over its drug-pricing policies, had previously delayed the release of its earnings. Its shares dropped sharply.
articles.abstract: The company, which is facing inquiries over its drug-pricing policies, had previously delayed the release of its earnings. Its shares dropped sharply.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of the embattled drug maker Valeant Pharmaceuticals dropped more than 50 percent on Tuesday after the company issued weak earnings guidance and warned of a possible default on some of its debt.

articles.headline: On Trade, Angry Voters Have a Point
articles.snippet: Recent studies suggest that the disruptions from freer trade, an issue in the current presidential campaign, are more persistent than once thought.
articles.abstract: Recent studies suggest that the disruptions from freer trade, an issue in the current presidential campaign, are more persistent than once thought.
articles.lead_paragraph: Were the experts wrong about the benefits of trade for the American economy?
